I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  the  Small  Business  and  Entrepreneurship  Development 
Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Improving Rural Small 
Business Access to Finance, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA.1 
  
The  project  will  enable  women’s  small  businesses  and  rural  small  businesses  to  grow, 
2. 
develop,  expand,  compete,  and  play  a  greater  income-generating role  in Uzbekistan. Through 
this financial  intermediation  loan,  participating  commercial  banks  (PCBs)  will  provide  subloans 
to small businesses. At least 30% of the subloans will be to women’s small businesses2 and at 
least 50% will be to small businesses outside the city of Tashkent. The project will be supported 
by  TA  to  strengthen  PCBs’  capacity  to  provide  loans  to  and  improve  the  entrepreneurial 
capacities of women’s small businesses and rural small businesses. The project implementation 
period is 2014–2017.  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
The  economic  significance  of  small  businesses  in  providing  jobs  and  driving  growth  is 
high  in  Uzbekistan.3 The  contribution  of  small  businesses  to  gross  domestic  product  (GDP) 
increased  from  35.0%  in  2003  to  54.6%  in  2012. 4  Small  businesses  are  mainly  active  in 
agriculture (98.0% of the sector output). Other important sectors include construction (70.7% of 
the sector output), retail trade (45.3%), and services (44.7%). In 2012, about 9.3 million people 
worked  in  small  businesses—or  75.2%  of the total  number  of  persons  employed.  At the  same 
time, 37.2% of total investments in 2012 went to small businesses. 
 
In  Uzbekistan,  48.8%  of  the  29.2  million  population  live  and  work  in  rural  areas.5 Low-
4. 
income  earners  in  Uzbekistan  accounted  for  17.5%  of  the  population  in  2011. 6  Small 
businesses  contribute  more  than  60.0%  of  gross  regional  product  in  9  of  14  regions,  with 
Syrdarya region being the highest (80.0%). The largest share of the total number of employed 
persons is in agriculture and forestry, accounting for 48.3% of employed women and 51.7% of 
employed men. However, the contribution of agriculture to GDP decreased from 30.0% in 2000 
to  about  18.0%  in  2011.  Of  the  micro  and  small  enterprises  registered  in  2012,  84.5%  were 
outside  the  city  of  Tashkent,  as  were  81.5%  of  all  individual  entrepreneurs  in  2011.  Male

 2 

 

entrepreneurship in rural areas is high in Namangan, accounting for 71.0% of total registration, 
followed by the Navoi, Fergana, and Bukhara regions (footnote 5).  

 
5. 
The  financial  sector  is  dominated  by  banks:  the  banking  subsector’s  assets  accounted 
for  37.0%  of  GDP  in  2012.  Eight  banks  with  state  ownership  accounted  for  76.1%  of  total 
banking  assets  in  2012.  The  total  banking  loan  portfolio  accounted  for  21.1%  of  GDP  and 
deposits accounted for 23.6% of GDP in 2012.7 Lending to small businesses comprised 26.3% 
of  banks’  outstanding  loans  in  2012  and  microcredit  loans  comprised  5.7%  of  banks’  total 
outstanding  loans.8 While  small  business  lending  has  doubled  since  2006  and  the  microcredit 
loan portfolio has grown nearly fourfold in that period, lending to women was less than 15.0% of 
total bank lending in 2012. 
 
Financial services and delivery mechanisms do not meet the needs of small businesses, 
6. 
particularly outside the city of Tashkent. The branch network is limited and rural areas have few 
points  of  service  terminals,  creating  constraints  for  existing  and  potential  bank  clients.  Cost  of 
transportation  and  time  spent  accessing  financial  services  are  other  limiting  factors.  Small 
businesses  have  limited  access  to  business  development  services  that  contribute  to  the 
efficiency,  profitability,  and  expansion  of  their  activities.  Focus  group  discussions  suggest  that 
small  businesses  lack  access  to  information  on  government  programs,  market  opportunities, 
suppliers,  competitors,  technology,  and  banking  products.  Weak  financial  literacy,  especially 
among  women’s  small  businesses  and  low-income  groups,  limits  their  access  to  financial 
services  and  constrains  their  entrepreneurial  capacity.  Very  limited  financial  services  and 
products  are  adapted  to  the  needs  of  rural  small  businesses,  which  are  largely  dependent  on 
agricultural  cycles.  Access  to  electronic  banking  (e-banking)  is  low.9 While  debit  cards  are the 
most developed payment channel, about 70.0% of households do not have such cards, making 
cash their only payment option.10 
 
7. 
Limited  access  to  bank  credit  and  the  high  cost  of  borrowing  are  among  the  largest 
impediments  to  small  businesses.  The  lack  of  liquidity  and  availability  of  capital,  coupled  with 
high  perceived  risks  and  high  administrative  costs  when  lending  to  small  businesses,  compel 
banks to charge high interest rates. Bank loans usually have short maturities, restraining small 
businesses  from  expanding  and  modernizing.  Only  one-third  of  the  total  microcredit  loan 
portfolio  of  banks  is for more  than  3 years;  the  rest  has  maturities  between 6  and  24  months. 
Weak bank risk management capacity restricts their lending, preventing engagement with small 
businesses that have little or no collateral. Insufficient collateral also limits the size of loans, thus 
restricting  small  businesses  from  borrowing  more  for  their  business  expansion  and  capital 
investments. Collateral requirements for small businesses (146.0% of the loan size) are higher 
than  for  large  enterprises  (128.0%  of  the  loan  size). 11  In  stakeholder  and  focus  group 
discussions,  insufficient  collateral  was  cited  as  the  single  greatest  impediment  to  borrowing.

Tashkent).

   3 

Common  forms  of  collateral  include  cars,  jewelry,  and  real  estate.  Banks  offer  third-party 
guarantors, but they are difficult to find for first-time borrowers as they are often considered high 
risk.  
 
The  proposed  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  loan  aims  to  improve  the  ability  of 
8. 
women’s small businesses and rural small businesses to operate and expand. It will help these 
entrepreneurs build productive enterprises in profitable sectors, operate to scale, access finance, 
and  benefit  from  economic  opportunities.  The  PCBs  will  benefit  from  increased  long-term 
finance  and  stronger  institutional  capacity,  which  will  enable  them  to  better  meet  the  financial 
services  demand  of  women’s  small  businesses  and  rural  small  businesses.  It  will  also  enable 
PCBs  to  (i)  provide  short-  and  medium-term  subloans  in  either  sum  or  US  dollars  to  small 
businesses;  (ii)  diversify  income  sources;  (iii)  spread  risk;  and  (iv)  increase  the  delivery  of 
financial  services  and  products  such  as  e-banking,  online  loan  applications,  and  services  to 
support  business  development.  The  attached  TA  will  support  project  implementation  by 
improving  the  capacity  of  PCBs,  their  client  small  businesses,  and  the  Central  Bank  of 
Uzbekistan (CBU).  

 
9. 
The  project  is  consistent  with  both  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  with  Uzbekistan 
and government policy. The country partnership strategy 2012–2016 and the country operations 
business  plan  2012–2014  support  government  reforms  to  enable  small  business  to  be  an 
engine  of  growth,  diversification,  and  investment  for  the  economy. 12 Presidential  resolutions 
support  microfinance  development  to  finance  small  businesses  and  raise  employment  and 
welfare. 13  State  programs  include  measures  to  enhance  women’s  role  in  governance  and 
improve the business environment. The project will build on two previous  loans that supported 
access  to  credit  for  micro  and  small  enterprises  and  job  creation.14 It  will  also  build  on  (i)  an 
equity investment in Ipak Yuli Bank to improve banking sector quality, increase lending to small 
and medium-sized enterprises, and help catalyze foreign investment in Uzbekistan; 15 and (ii) an 
integrated  rural  development  program  that  provides  access  to  long-term  housing  finance  and 
supports  the  building  of  new  houses  in  rural  areas. 16 Lessons  learned  include  the  need  to 
strengthen  bank  capacity  for  rural  outreach,  the  continued  need  to  target  women’s  small 
businesses, and the importance of closely monitoring PCBs during project implementation.17 In

ADB  conducts  reviews  to  ensure  compliance  with  eligibility  criteria  for  subloans  issued  under  the  project.  Only

Impact and Outcome 

consultations  with  the  government,  international  development  partners,  potential  PCBs, 
women’s  associations,  and  academia,  the  project  team  found  broad  support  for  the  proposed 
project.  
 
B. 
 
10. 
The  impact  will  be  viable  rural  small  businesses  with  women’s  participation.  The 
outcome  will  be  increased  financial  access  by  rural  small  businesses  with  women’s 
participation.18 
 
C. 
 
The project will have two outputs: (i) strengthened capacity of PCBs to deliver financial 
11. 
services to women’s small businesses and rural small businesses, and (ii) improved borrowing 
capacity of women’s small businesses and rural small businesses. The project loan will finance 
subloans under output 1, while the TA will support outputs 1 and 2. 
 
12. 
Output  1.  Strengthened  capacity  to  deliver  financial  services  to  women’s  small 
businesses  and  rural  small  businesses  includes  the  financial  capacity  of  PCBs  to  provide 
subloans, as supported by the ADB loan. To enable PCBs to better understand the challenges 
faced by women’s small businesses and rural small businesses in accessing finance, the TA will 
help strengthen the capacity of PCB staff to (i) design and conduct annual customer surveys on 
the demand for financial services and their quality, as well as needs for capacity building among 
bank clients, including financial literacy; (ii) assess existing lending strategies towards women’s 
small businesses and rural small businesses; and (iii) sensitize and train PCB staff on women’s 
entrepreneurship  needs  and  tailored  programs.  To  better  meet  client  demands  for  financial 
services, the TA will contribute to the design of at least two new financial products in each bank 
to  target  project  beneficiaries.  To  enable  PCBs  to  simplify  access  to  financial  services  and 
increase  their  outreach  to  rural  small  businesses,  the  TA  will  support  the  development  of  (i) 
online  systems  for  processing  loan  applications  and  e-banking,  and  (ii)  simplified  loan 
application procedures. To enable PCBs to better evaluate the potential risk posed by lending, 
mitigate  losses  from  bad  debts,  and  increase  efficiency  in  small  business  lending,  the  TA  will 
help  (i)  strengthen risk management  practices and  credit  assessment  standards,  including  the 
adoption  of  credit  scoring  techniques;  (ii)  adopt  International  Financial  Reporting  Standards 
(IFRS); (iii) develop monitoring and supervision methodology to prevent loan delinquency in the 
target group; and (iv) establish a monitoring and evaluation framework with sex-disaggregated 
data to track performance, outreach, impact, and achievement of targets and indicators for the 
ADB  project.  These  activities  will  enable  PCBs  to  increase  their  outreach  to  potential 
subborrowers and issue at least 5,000 new microcredit loans and 100 new small business loans 
under the project.19 
 
13. 
Output  2.  The  capacity  for  women’s  small  businesses  and  rural  small  businesses  to 
borrow  will  be  improved  through  awareness  campaigns  and  workshops.  To  strengthen  the 
entrepreneurial  capacities  of  women’s  small  businesses  and  rural  small  businesses,  and  to 
increase  their  access  to  financial  services,  the  TA  will  use  a  training-of-trainers  approach  to 

                                                                                                                                                       
subloans that meet the eligibility criteria will be credited under the project. The review is expected to be completed 
by mid-September 2013.

enable  PCBs  to  conduct  workshops  on  (i)  budget  planning,  accounting,  money,  and  inventory 
management; (ii) business plan development and marketing; (iii) financial literacy; and (iv) bank 
services  and  products.  These  services  will  help  small  businesses,  particularly  project 
beneficiaries, build productive enterprises in profitable sectors, operate to scale, access finance, 
benefit from economic opportunities, and improve subborrower loan repayment capacity. These 
steps  can  enable  small  businesses  to  have  a  greater  role  in  income-generating  activities  by 
building capacity of potential subborrowers and facilitating access to subloans under the project 
for  at  least  3,000  subborrowers.  It  can  contribute  to  an  increase  in  the  number  of  small 
businesses registered from 247,000 to at least 310,000 by project completion. 
 
D. 
 
The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $133.3  million.  To  effectively  support  government 
14. 
promotion  of  women’s  small  businesses  and  small  businesses  in  rural  areas,  the  government 
has requested a loan of $50 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources. The loan will have a 
20-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft 
loan and project agreements.  
 
The Republic of Uzbekistan as borrower will relend the proceeds from the ADB loan in 
15. 
US dollars through subsidiary loan agreements to PCBs that meet ADB eligibility criteria (para. 
22).20 PCBs  will  provide  $50  million  equivalent  in  counterpart  funding,  and  subborrowers  will 
provide  $33.33  million  as  equity  contributions.  Under  the  subsidiary  loan  agreements,  the 
government is expected to relend to the PCBs for 15 years, including a 5-year grace period. The 
government’s relending rate will be the interest rate charged by ADB for the loan plus an annual 
premium of 0.2% to cover administrative expenses and risks incurred by the government. The 
project investment and financing plan is presented in Table 1.

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
The proposed TA for Improving Rural and Women’s Small Business Access to Finance 
21. 
will  develop  PCBs’  capacity  for  financial  services  delivery  and  improve  the  entrepreneurial 
capacities of rural small businesses, including women’s businesses. The TA will start in January 
2014  and  will  be  completed  in  December  2015. It  will  provide five  international  consultants for 
10 person-months and three national consultants for 16 person-months to deliver three outputs: 
(i) improved capacity of PCBs to lend to women’s small businesses and rural small businesses; 
(ii)  improved  capacity  of  women’s  small  businesses  and  rural  small  businesses;  and  (iii) a 
stronger  regulatory  and  supervisory  framework  for  the  development  and  supervision  of  e-
banking,  including  controls  related  to  anti-money-laundering  and  combating  the  financing  of 
terrorism (AML/CFT). The TA will support a baseline survey for an impact evaluation study. The 
TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $550,000  equivalent,  of  which  $500,000  will  be  financed  on  a  grant 
basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-V).  The  government  will  provide 
counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  staff,  office  space,  logistical  support,  translation,  and 
facilitation  of  the  consultant’s  timely  access  to  information  and  stakeholders.  The  MOF  will  be 
the  executing  agency  for  the  TA.  The  CBU  and  PCBs  will  be  the  implementing  agencies. 
Individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time).

Economic and Financial 

 
A.

stakeholders. To  ensure  a financially  sustainable approach  to  enhancing the  capacity  of  small 
businesses—especially  women’s  businesses  and 
rural  areas—stakeholder 
consultations  were  undertaken  with  commercial  banks,  women’s  organizations,  international 
development partners, and the government. The consultations confirmed that a lack of finance

among  subborrowers  was  limiting  firm  creation  and  growth,  and  that  demand  exists  for  both 
sum-  and  US  dollar-denominated  subloans.  After  the  PCB  eligibility  criteria  were  defined,  a 
selection  process  identified  potential  PCBs  from  among  all  banks.  Under  the  eligibility  criteria, 
PCBs must (i) meet ADB‘s requirements on financial analysis, financial management systems, 
and integrity due diligence; (ii) be willing and able to grow, design, and service women’s small 
businesses and rural small businesses in line with the objectives of the project; (iii) comply with 
CBU  mandatory  prudential  standards,  and  AML/CFT  and  regulations  in  Uzbekistan;  and  (iv) 
comply with covenants in other ADB projects and/or programs in which they are engaged. 
 
23. 
The selection of potential PCBs was undertaken in three phases. In the first phase, ADB 
compiled  key  financial  indicators  for  all  active  commercial  banks  in  Uzbekistan.  In  the  second 
phase, ADB identified 11 banks that were largely in compliance with financial benchmark ratios, 
and sent letters inviting them to confirm their interest  in participating in the project and provide 
financial  data  on  their  benchmark  ratios  as  well  as  their  branch  networks.  In  the  third  phase, 
seven banks were requested to submit additional information, including more detailed financial 
information.  During  fact-finding  on  20–28  May  2013,  five  banks  that  responded  to  the  request 
for  additional  information  and  were  largely  in  compliance  with  the  benchmark  ratios  were 
reviewed  in  accordance  with  ADB  requirements:  financial  analysis,  assessment  of  financial 
management  systems,  and  integrity  due  diligence.  ADB  interviewed  the  five  banks  to  confirm 
their  commitment  to  the  project.  The  banks  provided  information  about  their  willingness  and 
ability  to  grow  and  service  women’s  small  businesses  and  rural  small  businesses.  Two  banks 
meet the eligibility criteria to participate in the project. One more PCB is expected to be added 
to the project provided it meets the eligibility criteria as stipulated under the project.  
 
Based  on  audited  financial  statements  for  2012,  the  capital  adequacy  ratio  of  the 
24. 
potential PCBs was equal to or higher than 12%. Their return on average assets was equal to or 
higher  than  1%.  Their  loan-to-deposit  ratio  was  under  100%;  their  cost-to-income  ratio  was 
under 75%; their nonperforming loans did not exceed 5%; and the maximum amount of risk on 
loans given  to one insider  was not  greater than 25%.25 The  PCBs  will  be  required  to maintain 
these  financial  performance  ratios  to  remain  eligible  intermediaries.26 The  CBU  has  confirmed 
that  the  potential  PCBs  meet  CBU  mandatory  prudential  standards  as  well  as  AML/CFT  laws 
and  regulations  in  Uzbekistan,  including  applicable  CBU  regulations. 27  The  potential  PCBs 
comply  with  covenants  in  other  ADB  projects  and/or  programs  in  which  they  are  engaged. 28 
Subborrower  and  subproject  eligibility  criteria  are  designed  to  ensure  viability  and  continued 
operational and financial soundness. The government and the CBU will support sustainability by 
(i)  allowing  PCBs  to  onlend  ADB  funds  at  market  interest  rates  for  qualified  subprojects;  (ii) 
permitting subborrowers to withdraw sum- or US dollar-denominated subloans in any legal form; 
and  (iii)  providing  ADB  with  timely,  complete,  accurate,  and  relevant  information  necessary  to 
monitor ADB’s design and monitoring framework.

B. 
 
25. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  MOF.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual (footnote 22). ADB’s requirements 
and policies on financial management reporting and auditing, procurement,29 and environmental 
and  social  safeguards  were  discussed  and  agreed  with  the  MOF  and  the  implementing 
agencies.  A  financial  management  assessment,  including  a  financial  analysis  of  the  potential 
PCBs,  indicated  that  (i)  the  banks  prepare  their  financial  statements  in  accordance  with 
International  Financial  Reporting  Standards;  (ii)  internal  audit  units  exist  at  each  bank  with  an 
independent  reporting  structure;  (iii)  the  financial  statements  are  audited  by  reputable 
internationally affiliated audit firms; (iv) formal risk management units exist; (v) capital adequacy 
ratios  are  above  regulatory  requirements;  (vi)  profitability  ratios  are  reasonable;  and  (vii)  net 
interest  margins  are  adequate.  Based  on  bank  call  reports  submitted  to  the  CBU,  the  PCBs 
were in accordance with prudential and regulatory benchmarks as of 31 December 2012. These 
benchmarks  include  capital  adequacy,  liquidity,  loan  losses,  and  open  foreign  currency 
positions. Weaknesses were identified in internal audit, risk management, accounting, credit risk 
assessment and appraisal, and reconciling procedures of project accounts. 
 
C. 
 
26. 
The  loan  supports  poverty  reduction  indirectly  through  its  focus  on  women’s  small 
businesses  and  rural  small  businesses.  The  loan  will  (i)  be  implemented  across  regions  in 
Uzbekistan;  (ii)  enable  small  businesses  to  play  a  greater  role  in  income-generating  activities; 
and (iii) help improve social inclusion, enhance welfare, and deepen economic growth. A gender 
assessment,  one  of  the  project  documents,  is  an  integral  part  of  the  project,  which  is 
categorized as effective gender mainstreaming. The project addresses women’s empowerment 
through access to financial resources, capacity building, and credit outreach activities.30 
 
D. 
 
27. 
The loan is categorized as financial intermediation (FI) for environment, and FI (treated 
as C) with respect to involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. Subprojects will not be 
eligible  for  financing  under  this  project  if  they  are  categorized  as  (i)  A  for  environment  under 
ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  (ii)  class  1  or  2  under  the  government’s 
environmental  impact  assessment  requirement, or  (iii)  having  involuntary  resettlement  impacts 
or impacts on Indigenous Peoples. Activities on ADB’s prohibited investment activities list in the 
Safeguard Policy  Statement  are  excluded.  The  PCBs  will  implement  environmental  and social 
management  systems  (ESMSs)  acceptable  to  ADB  to  ensure  proposals  for  subprojects  are 
screened  for  environmental  and  social  impacts  and  (if  applicable)  mitigating  measures  are  in 
place.  Safeguards  due  diligence  has  been  carried  out  according  to  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement requirements for financial intermediation projects. The assessed PCBs are expected 
to have staff capacity and an established ESMS. Before the loan is disbursed, ADB will ensure 
that  the  ESMSs  of  the  PCBs  are  operational  in  banks  already  engaged  in  ADB  projects,  or 
established  in  banks  that  have  not  participated  in  ADB  projects  in  accordance  with  ADB 
requirements.  ADB  will  provide  capacity  building  workshops  to  PCB  staff.  Each  PCB  will  be 
required to designate at least one staff member to be responsible for ESMS implementation.
